title: Understanding desistance from sexual offending
abstractText:
This research seeks to fill an important gap in the literature around ex-offender reintegration by exploring the specific socio-cognitive changes that underpin desistance among individuals who have previously committed sexual offences against children.

Using life history interviews with a sample of desisting (3-5 years post conviction) and persisting offenders (recently re-convicted) it explores how and why some individuals convicted of serious sexual crimes are able to move on from such pasts and successfully desist from future re-offending.

The interpretive analysis of participants’ subjective life experiences will enable an understanding of how desisting individuals are able to “make sense” of their past lives and the serious harms they have caused, how individuals can overcome the personality traits and predispositions that may have contributed to their offending, and how they have been able to transcend the shame and stigma related to this type of offending. In other words, the themes and dynamics of desistance identified in this research are likely to be distinct from the risk factors that are well known in the research literature.

 

This contribution would have obvious and direct benefits for the development of theory and therapeutic work aimed at supporting desistance among those convicted of previous sexual offences.
impactText: The findings have not been used at the time of reporting - data analysis has just been completed and we are 15 months in to a 40 month research project.
